articles.headline: Fed Chief Says Outlook Is Positive
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke predicted that unemployment was likely to remain low over the next two years even as inflation declined slightly.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke predicted that unemployment was likely to remain low over the next two years even as inflation declined slightly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 — The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, gave Congress an upbeat view of the economy on Wednesday, predicting that unemployment was likely to remain low over the next two years even as inflation declined slightly.

articles.headline: Germany Battling Rising Tide of Corporate Corruption
articles.snippet: A prosecutor in Frankfurt believes that illicit dealings have helped to create the success of German exporters.
articles.abstract: A prosecutor in Frankfurt believes that illicit dealings have helped to create the success of German exporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Feb. 14 — Wolfgang Schaupensteiner has never been so busy.

articles.headline: Freedom for Prisoners of Voice Mail
articles.snippet: If you’re tired of spending time and cellphone minutes listening to the voice-mail lady, try new tools that convert voice messages to text and deliver them by e-mail.
articles.abstract: If you’re tired of spending time and cellphone minutes listening to the voice-mail lady, try new tools that convert voice messages to text and deliver them by e-mail.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you dig down past the megahertz and pixels and scroll wheels, all technology boils down to variations of “time is money” — and nobody knows it better than cellphone carriers. Every time you use your cellphone, you’re spending money.

articles.headline: The ‘Toyota Way’ Is Translated for a New Generation of Foreign Managers
articles.snippet: At the Toyota Institute, promising executives learn some of the most prized management secrets in corporate Japan.
articles.abstract: At the Toyota Institute, promising executives learn some of the most prized management secrets in corporate Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOYOTA CITY, Japan — It does not occupy much space on the office wall, but Latondra Newton calls it the hardest thing for Toyota’s new American employees to accept: those colored bar charts against a white bulletin board, in plain view for all to see.

articles.headline: Bush Declares Iran’s Arms Role in Iraq Is Certain
articles.snippet: President Bush said he did not know whether Iran’s highest officials had ordered attacks on American troops.
articles.abstract: President Bush said he did not know whether Iran’s highest officials had ordered attacks on American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 — President Bush said Wednesday that he was certain that factions within the Iranian government had supplied Shiite militants in Iraq with deadly roadside bombs that had killed American troops. But he said he did not know whether Iran’s highest officials had directed the attacks.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Marc Santora

articles.headline: A Guilty Plea for Options Backdating
articles.snippet: The founder and former head of Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, pleaded guilty to falsifying records.
articles.abstract: The founder and former head of Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, pleaded guilty to falsifying records.
articles.lead_paragraph: The founder and former head of Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, pleaded guilty to falsifying records in a stock-option-backdating scheme and agreed to help state authorities investigate the company, the Manhattan district attorney said yesterday.

articles.headline: A Cheeky Broadsheet’s Tabloid Makeover
articles.snippet: The New York Observer’s new tabloid format is still pinkish, and still plays host to some terrific writing. But reading the new Observer also provides a palpable feeling of loss.
articles.abstract: The New York Observer’s new tabloid format is still pinkish, and still plays host to some terrific writing. But reading the new Observer also provides a palpable feeling of loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Observer, which hit New York City streets Wednesday in a new tabloid format, has always conveyed something about the person holding it. As both accessory and artifact, its peachy hue conveys a certain retro chic, and its size, at least until yesterday, suggested the bearer was a person of sprawling, catholic interests, media gossip chief among them.

articles.headline: Detroit’s Slump Could Break Up Chrysler Group
articles.snippet: The lesson of this decade for automakers? Better to go it alone than bulk up through mergers and alliances.
articles.abstract: The lesson of this decade for automakers? Better to go it alone than bulk up through mergers and alliances.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Feb. 14 — Every decade provides a new lesson for the American automobile industry.

articles.headline: Russians to Vote, but Some Parties Lose in Advance
articles.snippet: Regional elections in March will preview coming national elections in which choices will be severely limited at best.
articles.abstract: Regional elections in March will preview coming national elections in which choices will be severely limited at best.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Two candidates in local elections here in March, a soccer star and figure skating champion, have no known intention of giving up sports for legislative politics. If they win, as they almost certainly will, their Kremlin-friendly parties, not the voters, will choose the candidates to fill their seats.
